snippet: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Monday's selection includes plans for the Pebble watch, which raised more than $10 million on Kickstarter, Nokia's recipe for rejuvenation b...
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Monday's selection includes plans for the Pebble watch, which raised more than $10 million on Kickstarter, Nokia's recipe for rejuvenation by making dramatic changes in smartphones and a list of possessions the wife of the jailed chief of Megaupload wants returned.

headline.main: Today's Scuttlebot: Virtual Robbery, and Tracking Apple Rumors

snippet: Several users of Apple's iMessage, an Internet-based messaging service, have been reporting problems with the service on Apple support forums. The problem appears to be tied to the beta version of Apple's messaging software for the Mac.
abstract: Several users of Apple's iMessage, an Internet-based messaging service, have been reporting problems with the service on Apple support forums. The problem appears to be tied to the beta version of Apple's messaging software for the Mac.

headline.main: A Potential Fix for iMessage Woes

snippet: AirPlay, a software tool included with Apple's iPads and iPhones, is widely viewed as being potentially disruptive to the cable industry, because it makes it easy for people to view a broad variety of Internet content on a television. Time Warner ...
abstract: AirPlay, a software tool included with Apple's iPads and iPhones, is widely viewed as being potentially disruptive to the cable industry, because it makes it easy for people to view a broad variety of Internet content on a television. Time Warner Cable's leader, however, hasn't heard of it.

headline.main: Head of Time Warner Cable Is Unfamiliar With Apple's AirPlay

snippet: When it comes to the traditional screen that families gather around, live television is competing against a growing array of self-selected content, and audiences are bolting.
abstract: David Carr The Media Equation observes that live television viewing is competing against a growing array of self-selected content, and audiences are bolting; notes Horizon Media reports online viewing is up more than 46 percent in the past year, and live ratings for network programs have declined for 14 consecutive quarters.

headline.main: A TV Schedule in the Hands of Whoever Holds the Remote
headline.print_headline: A TV Schedule in the Hands of Whoever Holds the Remote

snippet: Madison Avenue, even if it canâ€™t always get what it wants from television anymore, still believes it gets most of what it needs.
abstract: Stuart Elliott Advertising column observes that despite declining ratings for many television shows and shifting viewing habits, advertising on TV still delivers results major marketers want; notes Nielsen reports 2011 TV ad revenue in the United States was $71.8 billion, up 5 percent from 2010 and larger than any other medium.

headline.main: Amid Media Upheavals, Television Holds Sway
headline.print_headline: Amid Media Upheavals, Television Holds Sway
